sen.j: 銀本位制（ぎんほんいせい、silver standard <英>）とは、一国の貨幣制度の根幹を成す基準を銀と定めた。
sen.e: The silver standard is a system in which silver forms the basis of a monetary system of a country.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: The silver standard is a system in which silver forms the basis of a monetary system of a country.
The silver standard is a system in which silver forms the basis of a monetary system of a country.

sen.j: その基礎となる貨幣、すなわち本位貨幣を銀貨とし、これに自由鋳造、自由融解を認め、無制限通用力を与えた制度である。
sen.e: The base currency, or the standard currency, is silver coins, allowed free coinage and free fusing and given power to circulate unlimitedly.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: The base currency, or the standard currency, is silver coins, allowed free coinage and free fusing and given power to circulate unlimitedly.

sen.j: この場合、その国の通貨は一定量の銀の量を持って表すことができ、商品の価格も銀の価値を標準として表示される。
sen.e: In this case, the currency of the country is represented as a certain amount of silver, and silver value is set as default for commodity price.
In this case, the currency of the country is represented as a certain amount of silver, and silver value is set as default for commodity price.

sen.j: 実際には、銀のみを法的に本位貨幣とする純粋な銀本位制の例は、歴史上あまり多くない。
sen.e: In fact, there are not many examples of a genuine silver standard for which silver is the only legal standard currency in history.

sen.j: 日本の江戸時代においては、金貨（小判）、銀貨（丁銀）、そして小額貨幣として銭貨がそれぞれ事実上の本位貨幣として無制限通用を認められるという、いわゆる三貨制度が存在していた。
sen.e: In the Edo period, there was Sanka seido (Tokugawa coinage) in which Koban (oval gold coins), Chogin (silver coins), and Senka (small coins) were unlimitedly passable as standard coins in effect.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: In the Edo period, there was Sanka seido (Tokugawa coinage) in which Koban (oval gold coins), Chogin (silver coins), and Senka (small coins) were unlimitedly passable as standard coins in effect.

sen.j: しかし、実態は東日本で主に金貨、西日本で主に銀貨が流通するというものであった。
sen.e: In fact, however, gold coins circulated in eastern Japan while silver coins circulated in western Japan.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: In fact, however, gold coins circulated in eastern Japan, while silver coins circulated in western Japan.
sen.cmt: whileの前にコンマを挿入しました。

sen.j: このように、銀貨と金貨を共に本位貨幣とする制度を金銀複本位制という。
sen.e: The system in which both silver and gold coins were set as standard currency is called bimetallism.
In this way, the system in which both silver and gold coins were set as standard currency is called bimetallism.
sen.cmt: 文頭に「このように」の意味を追加挿入しました。
sen.e: In this way, the system in which both silver and gold coins were set as standard currency is called bimetallism.

sen.j: しかし、金銀地金の確保などの事情により、この金銀複本位制が形骸化して銀貨のみが流通した。
sen.e: Prevented from securing gold and silver metal, however, the bimetallism became a mere formality that only silver coins circulated.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: According to some reasons such as securing gold and silver metal, however, the bimetallism became a mere formality that only silver coins circulated.
sen.cmt: 文頭をAccording toに変更し一部訂正しました。

sen.j: つまり、事実上の銀本位制度となる場合が少なからず見られる。
sen.e: Therefore, the system often goes to silver standard in effect.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Therefore, the system often goes to silver standard in effect.

sen.j: 一例として19世紀、ヨーロッパ諸国の多くも金銀複本位制を採っていたが、銀産出高の増加などにより銀の市場価格が下落、金貨との法定金銀比価との間に開きができた。
sen.e: As an example, in the nineteenth century, many of European countries employed the bimetallism, but there was wide gap of legal exchange ratio between gold and silver because silver production increased and its market value declined.

As an example, in the nineteenth century, many of European countries adopted the bimetallism, but there was wide gap of legal exchange ratio between gold and silver because silver production increased and its market value declined.

sen.j: この場合、銀貨を流通させて金貨を退蔵した方が有利な為（グレシャムの法則）、なし崩し的に事実上の銀本位制となった。
sen.e: In such cases, the system gradually eroded and changed to the silver standard because it is advantageous to circulate silver coins and hoard gold coins (Gresham's law).
In such cases, the system gradually eroded and changed to the silver standard, because it was advantageous to circulate silver coins and hoard gold coins (Gresham's law).

sen.j: この時期の銀の市場価格の変動は大きくまた下落傾向が顕著であった為、そして、その当時世界経済の主導的地位を占めていたイギリスが既に金本位制に転じていた為、銀本位制諸国は深刻な影響をうけ、19世紀の終りにはほとんどの国が金本位制に転じた。
sen.e: Since fluctuation of market value of silver during this period was significant and tended to decline remarkably and the United Kingdom, who led the world economy around that time, already shifted to gold standard, countries which employed silver standard were seriously affected, so most of the countries shifted to the gold standard in the end of the nineteenth century.

sen.j: 日本においては1871年6月に「新貨条例」を制定し、形式上は金本位制が採用された。
sen.e: In Japan, New Currency Regulation was established in June of 1871, and the gold standard was employed formally.
In Japan, New Currency Regulation was established in June, 1871, and the gold standard was adopted formally.

sen.j: しかし、当時は東洋市場においては銀貨による対外支払いが一般的であった為、1円銀貨（量目は416グレーン）ならびに、当時の洋銀に相当する420グレインの量目の貿易銀を発行し、貿易などの対外支払用貨幣として使用した。
sen.e: In the East market during that time, however, foreign payment was generally done by silver coins; therefore, 1 yen silver coin (weighed value: 416 grain) and silver coins of weighed value of 420 grain equivalent to German silver were issued for trade, and used as means of foreign payment for trade.

sen.j: 1878年には1円銀貨の国内一般通用が認められ、事実上の金銀複本位制となった。
sen.e: In 1878, 1 yen silver coins were approved for circulation in Japan to become virtual bimetallism.

sen.j: しかし、金貨の流出と政府不換紙幣の大量発行によって、金貨はほとんど流通しなくなった。
sen.e: However, gold coins became scarcely circulated because they outflowed and the government issued huge sum of irredeemable currency.

sen.j: さらに松方デフレ後の1885年には、初の日本銀行券（大黒図案の100円、10円、1円の兌換銀券）による銀兌換が開始された。
sen.e: In 1885 after the Matsukata deflation, conversion of silver by first Bank of Japan notes (100 yen, 10 yean and 1 yen of silver conversion notes with a picture of Daikoku [the god of wealth]) was started.

sen.j: 1897年に正式に金本位制を採用するまで、事実上の銀本位制が継続した。
sen.e: The silver standard continued in effect until gold standard was formally employed in 1897.

sen.j: なお、中国では辛亥革命後も銀本位制が継続された。
sen.e: In China, the silver standard continued after the Xinhai Revolution.

sen.j: しかし、世界恐慌による金融市場の混乱による銀錠の流出を受けて1935年に銀本位制を放棄（銀元廃両改元）（管理通貨制度に基づく法幣導入）をした。
sen.e: However, confusion of financial market because of the Great Depression led outflow of silver coins, so the silver standard was abandoned (the abandonment of the old "tael" and its replacement with the "yuan"; adoption of legal currency based on controlled currency system) in 1935.
